Burlingame, CA 3/16/2012 I'm a strong supporter of the humane society so this is my preferred thrift store for dropping off goods to donate. As a shopper, this is actually also my preferred thrift store to hunt for bargains on used items. The volunteers check through all donations and it seems to me that they mainly keep merchandise that is in pretty good shape. For example, I don't come across stained clothes as often as I tend to see at Goodwill. They also have 50% off sales several times during the year which are very popular, so if you hear of one, go early for more selection.

Sebastopol, CA 3/13/2012 2 Check-ins Here This place has tons of everything!
They have a huge furniture selection and at prices to make things move. I took away one star because they have so much furniture it's hard to browse without fear of something toppling over on you.
I love charity thrift stores because they're usually run by cute little old ladies who are too cool to stay at home all day--and this place is no exception. Everyone is friendly and ready to help and answer any questions.
I've gotten some cool cactus here as well as a leather mini-skirt for $15! I beat myself up for the Mid-Century modern dresser I let slip through my grasp.
The parking lot next door makes it easy to load your trunk full of treasures. Whenever I have to take my husband to SFO, I make sure to include a stop here.

Bay Area 3/23/2012 GREAT little store, lovely staff and awesome store manager (John), but BEWARE the incredibly rude, curt and just plain weird donation center lady who "runs" the donation area--we were greeted as if we had just broken a fine China set in their store...?!? We went out of our way to choose this place because we are ardent animal lovers and support all causes that give $ to animal related places and charities. We regretted it as soon as we had to deal with the weird donation lady.
She had a dour look on her face the entire time. She has medium long brown hair and fair eyes, medium height.
We all have drama in our lives, but really, leave yours at home and don't treat community members who are DONATING valuable items as if they are dipped in sh*t. Awful. It's a shame, because we really love that store, but that lady is so VERY unwelcoming and cold. If possible, give your donations to the younger girl in the back or one of the senior citizens who assist, but stay away from that lady. Bad vibes!!
OR donate to your local Goodwill.

San Francisco, CA 4/25/2011 I don't even know where to begin, all I can get out at the moment is: I love this place!!
Let's start with parking. Parking is super easy. There is a parking lot right beside the store. It is metered, however one quarter gets you at LEAST 25 minutes. Amazing! The store itself is very organized. Furniture in the front, books in the back, and racks of clothes in between. There is also both a men's and women's restroom as well as two fitting rooms. The selection is great! The prices stay around one digit. I walked out with a $4 Michael Kors lace tanktop and a $7 cream cable knit sweater. I would have walked out with more but my cousin beat me to the cash register with items we both wanted. There is a resident cat who wanders around but it didn't bother me one bit. I love this place!! I will definately be coming back very soon!

Silicon Valley, CA 12/17/2008 The Parental Unit and I decided to do something different in terms of gift giving this year after I suggested we come up with a fixed amount to spend on one another. I then suggested we shop at thrift stores just to make it interesting since we both have just about everything we could ever want already. The game is on!
I went in knowing that my chances were slim of finding what I 'wanted' so I just went in open to what would be there. Unfortunately, I missed the 'everything 50% off' day but still got some nice deals:
*Five bestseller books for $10 (for me) *One blockbuster movie (Mom - she's never seen Indiana Jones!) *Gap silk sweater (Not sure if I'm keeping this for me or not) *Paris Las Vegas fleece hoodie (Mom - she loves to walk out in the cold) *SF 49er stadium cushion (Mom - for sitting on cold benches) *Lucky Brand tshirt (Mom - she's a bit of a thrift store label diva) *Plastic water pitcher (Me - for iced tea next summer)
$29.53 spent and she'll be thrilled that it will benefit animals since she's all about pets. Would have been flat-out blown away if they'd had an Apple arm band for her ipod. Oh, well. Maybe Best Buy will have it on sale. :)
Parking is tough but I found a space on Chula Vista about 2.5 blocks away.

Los Angeles, CA 6/18/2010 When I was little, my mom and I used to drive down to San Mateo to shop for furniture at the Pick of the Litter. Now, it's even closer to home, so my mom and I still bond over raw food from Que SeRAW down the street and a shopping trip into Pick of the Litter.
I can't say enough good stuff about this place. Really, it should be more like a list: - They have cats. I'm SOLD. - They usually have some really cute antique jewelry in the front. - Rich Burlingame ladies continually drop off their Ann Taylor and BCBG stuff, so stuff is always ripe for the picking. - They have a great book collection at great prices. - You can usually bargain with the staff if you're feeling poor. - Great furniture and housewares selection - The proceeds go to helping animals.
So this place is definitely worth planning your day around their limited hours. Get yourself a cute new purse and support kittens! Yeah!

San Francisco, CA 3/6/2010 Fantastic little thrift shop that give all proceeds to the SPCA! (help the little homeless chihuahuas out! *wo0of* *meow*)
Mind you, I am just not a thrift shop type of gal. People that shop at thrift stores LITERALLY come from all walks of life.
-people who want new clothes but would rather buy used clothes because it's cheaper -hipsters and scene kids thrifting for the sake of trendiness -people looking for that hidden gem
Then there's me, curious, but not quite into digging through old, used things that may closely resemble trash.
Ah...I'm not talking shit, but that's the case with most thrift stores. Pick of the litter is entirely opposite and is always kept neat and tidy. I love walking through the store just browsing quickly... I rarely DIG because ... well maybe i'm just not that hardcore yet. For now, it'll be one of my fav thrift stores...(if i ever decide to go thrifting again) I think it makes me appreciate it more because it's proceeds funds the homeless animals. I love em.
Here's a tip, every THIRD tuesday of the month, it's 50% off everything in the store! =)

They have a meter parking lot, which is nice since finding parking on or right off of Broadway can sometimes be a huge hassle. It's pretty small, so it's easy to keep tidy and organized and you can make donations easily in the front.

Burlingame, CA 12/26/2009 I started becoming disenchanted with thrift stores on the peninsula. They were all way overpriced and the stuff was mostly trash. I felt this way until I discovered Pick of the Litter. It is a lot smaller than Goodwill or the Salvation Army, but it is stocked with great treasures and everything is cheap! I've found Ferragamo shoes for $5, amazing records for pennies and great jewelry. This place really is a gem, I almost wish I could keep it to myself, but considering that the profits go to the SPCA, everyone should know about it. I also love that sometimes there are cats waiting to be adopted that you can pet while looking around. They also have 50% off sales, mostly on holidays for you that are looking for extra deals.

Burlingame, CA 1/13/2012 I am a fairly regular patron of "The Pick". I am always happy to purchase goods there to benefit the animals. The volunteers are friendly and helpful. I have come away with some great finds over the years. There are my three stars. Two were left blank because of the following. A great deal of the merchandise sits in the store for way too long. If things don't move after a certain period of time, they should be put in a clearance area at rock bottom price and off loaded. At times, the line at the register becomes exceedingly long. I have left without purchasing something if I see this happening. I have waited as long as 20 minutes to check out. It would be nice if there were someone in back that could pinch hit if it was apparent the cashier was overwhelmed. Help her bag and wrap or open another register! Just peek over and see how she is doing every 15 minutes or so. I am not talking about sale Tuesdays. It can get busy on just a regular day. Please visit the store. It is such a wonderful cause!
